The Williams Memorial Expedition to South America consisted
of Prof. Edward W. Berry, professor of paleontology; Prof. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., associate
professor of economic geology,
and Mr. Luis Sbanez Velasco, a
graduate student in the Department of Geology and a native of

PROF. JOSEPH T. SINGEWALD. JR.

Bolivia. The party sailed from
New York on April 17 and reached
Callao, Peru, on May 9. Stops
were made at Port au Prince,
Haiti, in the Canal Zone and at
the Peruvian ports of Eku, Paeas,
mayo and Salaverry en route to
Callao, which afforded brief opportunities for the members of
the expedition to go ashore and
make hasty observations on the
local geology. A week was spent
at Lima, the capital of Peru, in
getting acquainted with the Peruvian geologists and mining engineers, studying the collections of
the Peruvian Bureau of Mines and
Mining School, and making short
excursions to nearby points of geologic interest.
On May 16 the main range of
the Andes was crossed by rail
and the end of the line reached
at Huancayo. The following day
a trip on mule-back over the
range again and back to the sea
at Pisco was commenced, which
lasted until June 2 and which required traveling 250 miles on
mules. En route stops were made
at the mining districts of Huancavelica and Santa Ines. The

The intelligence tests on students entering the Department of
Engineering are intended as an
experiment to determine whether
it is possible to substitute for the
present method of entrance examinations some other form of
test which would determine the
fitness of the student to follow
courses in the University and
also his fitness for entering the
profession of engineering.
Present methods of examination are believed to work hardships in a number of cases and
to keep out a number of students
who would undoubtedly make successful engineers. On the other
hand, the present method does admit students who have acquired
a certain facility in preparing particular subjects and passing written examinations on them. These
students in some cases fail to
show special aptitude for the profession of engineering. The tests
give the student an opportunity
to demonstrate how well he can
use whatever information he has
on relatively simple but normal
problems and to bring out such
special talents as he may have,
leading to particular vocational
service.
The tests will be held on two
days and are six in number, three
on each day. The tests of the
first day are in simple mathematical or common sense problems.
Those on the second day are intended to test the special fitness
of the student for the profession
of engineering. These embrace
certain psychological tests and
simple questions in physics and
everyday technical information.
The tests are in no wise intended
to investigate the knowledge of
the student in the particular subject, but rather the facility with
which he can apply such common
knowledge as he should certainly
already possess.
When these several tests have
been checked up against subsequent scholastic performance and
possibly with some criteria of professional success, it should be possible to ascertain whether and in
what direction we should make
changes in our present methods
of examination:

NEWSHOLME TO GIVE LECTURES J. H. U. SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION

Debating Council Considers Rules to
Govern Annual Triangle Debate—
Southern Oratorical Contest
March the Fifth.

Elaborate Plan of Lectures Formed in
School of Hygiene. and Public
Health—Attendance Open
to All Students.

Scientific Association Reorganized—illustrated Lecture Given by Mr.
Cockayne of New Zealand-Prof.
Ames is the Chairman.

At the last meeting of the Debating Council the chief topics of
dirassion were the method of
Judging the, triangle debate for
1920 and what the subject should
be. The problem that presented
the most difficulty was how to
have the teams debate on homeground and at the same time obtain impartial judges. North Carolina and Virginia, both situated in
small towns, experience more
difficulty in obtaining these results than does Johns Hopkins,
who can select its judges from all
Baltimore. It was finally decided,
liowever to indorse a new plan instigated by Virginia, namely, to
call in an outside professional
judge and pay him to render his
decision with the reasons for his
conclusions.
Several possible subjects were
discussed and were finally mailed
to North Carolina and Virginia,
for their approval, in the following order:
1. That all labor disputes on
railroads and in coal mines should
be settled by compulsory arbitration if agreement cannot otherwise be reached.
2. That the city manager plan
Should be adopted in Americium
municipalities.
3. That the railroads of the
United States should be nationalized under a plan whereby'control
would be equally divided among
representatives of management, Of
labor and of the public.
The Council is especially anxious to get the topic selected, so
that the junior-senior debate can
be held before Christmas and
thereby spread the literary contests more evenly over the entire
year.

Lectures on "Public Health Administration" and on "Epidemiology" in relation thereto, by Sir
Arthur Newsholme, K. C. B., M.
D., will be given at 5 o'clock P.
M. on Tuesdays and Thursdays,
beginning Tuesday, October 7, at
the School of Hygiene and Public
Health, 312 West Monument
street. While intended primarily
for students in the School of Hygiene and Public Health, the lectures are open to students in
other departments of the University, and especially to those interested in public health work.
The following topics will be
discussed:
PART I.
1. History of public health administration, central and local.
2. Relation of health officers to
local and central authorities.
3. Qualifications and terms of
appointment of health officers.
4. Interrelations of public
health administration.
5. Public health administration in relation to medical and
nursing practitioners.
6. Registration and notification of births, deaths and sickness.
7. Methods of surveying a district.
8. Methods of investigatingdisease.
9. Preparation of reports.

The Scientific Association of
the Johns Hopkins University,
which has been more or less in the
background during the last few
years has been revived and reorganized.
Prof. Joseph S. Ames was elected chairman for this year. The
Executive Committee consists of
Prof. Edward B. Matthews, chairman, and of Professors Joseph C.
W. Frazer, Burton E. Livingston, Samuel 0. Mast and Frank
Morley.

PART II.
1. Hygiene of infancy and
childhood.
2. The hygiene of school life.
3. Industrial hygiene.
4. Hospital provision and • administration.
5. The control of special diseases and conditions.

The plans of the association for
this year is to arrange for four
lectures, the last of which will be
followed by a dinner. These lectures will be _delivered by prominent speakers fro-m various fields
of science and who are not connected with the University.
The first of the series of four
regular meetings was held in the
geology laboratory, Civil Engineering Hall, on Wednesday,. November 5 at 5 o'clock P. M. Mr.
Alfred fl. Cockayne, government
biologist of the Dominion of New
Zealand, gave a long, illustrated
lecture on "The Vegetation of New
Zealand and Its Relation to Agriculture." Mr. Cockayne's lecture
was primarily of interest to biologists, but the statements he made
were of equal interest to the eco-.
mimic geologist and to the student
of nature. There were excellent
illustrations of diverse tropical
trees and shrubs, especially of the
perching variety and of the vegethtion in very damp climates,
where plants develop breathing
roots. Over one-fourth of the four
thousand miles of seacoast of the
New Zealand Islands is covered by
sand dunes. Attempts have been
made to harness these migrating
dunes, and several illustrations
were shown to demonstrate how
acres and acres of sandy land
have been fixed by sedges and
other vegetation.
The lectures are open to any interested persons, and will be duly
announced.

BALTIMORE, MD:,

NOV. 11, 1919

Spirit and Cash Wanted.

Let us catch the spirit at the
- mass-meeting next Wednesday. It
is for the purpose of rousing enthusiasm for the new dormitory.
We don't think it needs much
rousing. It is what Hopkins men
have been dreaming of for generations, and none will be so affected
as the present undergraduates.
But enthusiasm backed with
practical means will count more
than enthusiasm alone. Ten dollars from every undergraduate is
not much, viewed singly, but collectively it will help a lot.
A Challenge.

Two little freshmen sat in the
middle of the fountain, on a rickety crate, fishing, and smiling
naively=as a freshman should
smile, — at the howling sophs
grouped around. They were thus
being ignominiously punished for
some infraction of the freshman
regulations.
It was amusing, of course, but
this incident had a deeper significance. It was one of the many
little signs of an undercurrent of
life and spirit around the University. Hazing has formerly been
considered a part of college life.
Now it is forbidden by the Dean.
But he does sanction harmless
punishment of freshmen who are
not inclined to behave as "freshies" should. And it is gratifying
to see the way the sophomore vigilance committee is taking care of

incorrigibles and those who do
not know any better.
This type of interest is a good
sign of college spirit, and has
been most efficacious in swelling
the attendance of first year men
in the rooting section at football
games, and in constraining them
to a closer observance of the "ten
commandments"; but, college
spirit in general should be more
constructive than primitive. There
should be a still larger participation in activities and in the support of our teams.
The only way to get anything
out of college life is to put something into it. There are some
among us who carry more than
their share of college honors and
unfortunately there are some indifferent ones, who selfishly lead
the life of a studious hermit.
These should observe that they
are robbing themselves of unnumbered delights and benefits
that the others are enjoying. They
too, can feel the spirit of Hopkins, and reap lifelong benefits
from the experience and pleasant
associations obtained while taking part in undergraduate life,
and becoming identified with
some particular activities. There
are honors for all who would
achieve them.
A Relic of Barbarism.

Should one wish to see a
Twentieth Century survival of the
day when decades ago our primeval ancestors found it necessary
to Dght in order to eat, let him
venture—if he dares—into the
'basement of "The Barn," where
at lunch time there is staged
daily a battle royal, all for a
sandwich and a bottle of milk.
In a small room is placed a
still smaller counter, from behind which are dispensed a limited supply of not altogether nutritious sandwiches, pies of the
ultra-indigestible variety, candies
and pint bottles • of milk with
straws thrown in- as a means of
imbibition. Somewhat fagged from
a morning of classes, the student
enters "The Barn," knowing what
is ahead of him, and resigns himself to his fate. He is at once
lost in a milling, moiling mass of
humanity, struggling with belligerent, determined elbows to reach
t' at common goal, the counter.
At last he gets there and grabs;
then comes the fight to get out
through the hungry mob, who
press with unyielding force towards the fodder.
By some miracle he escapes,
and sinks exhausted into an empty seat, if there is yet one of the
few vacant. He devours with
avidity what is left of his purchase, chats with some fellow sufferer, and then returns to classroom or to laboratory more tired
than before—of course sufficiently
nourished to get something out of
an afternoon of hard work.
It would seem that enough has
been said. That a hungry, or improperly nourished man can not

accomplish much in mental endeavors is known to everyone.
Something must be done to give
Hopkins students, who can not
conveniently get a decent lunch
elsewhere, a wholesome lunch here
on the campus.
A Laboratory Expe, iment in Labor
Problems.

The talk of liss Matyas to the
class in Political Economy IV was
very interesting. She presented
the cake, and told the story from
the workers' point of view, and in
that respect her talk might be regarded as a laboratory experiment
in labor problems. We hope that
the University will continue this
broad policy of having people actually engaged in practical affairs
talk to the students on topics of
such vital interest. "Veritas vos
Liberabit" be our motto and let
us not fail to avail ourselves of
every opportunity to learn the
truth of such matters.
In this connection, also, THE
NEWS-LETTER COmmendS the effort
of the Social Science Club in making an effort to study the real
problems of life.
Mass-meeting.

Hoffman opened the mass-meeting of last Friday by lamenting
the poor attendance at the meeting. With 800 students at the
University the hall should have
been packed, but it was not. He
then announced that there would
be a mass-meeting on next Wednesday for the benefit of the
$300,000 meniorial dormitory.
Jones then congratulated the
freshmen on their good showing
at the games.
Leber made the following announcements: Money will be collected next Friday to get bands,
if enough money is raised there
will, be bands at each of the three
games. On the night before the
St. John's game a bonfire will be
lighted where the hangar stood.
Each freshman sometime during
that day must report to a member
of the sophomore "Pep" Committee with some boxes or barrels. After the fire a parade
will proceed throughout the city.
On the day of the Western Maryland game all the freshmen will
carry banners bearing the inscription, "Beat Western Maryland !"
On the (lay of the St. John's
game a column Vill be formed at
1 o'clock at Mt. Royal avenue and
Calvert street extending to Homewood.
After , these announcements,
there was a yell practice.
The University of Wisconsin
has had a record-breaking registration this year. A student body
of 6,800 men and women has entered the school making an attendance of nearly 2,000 more than
at any time in the past.

Quacks From A Quack.

The editors Of THE NEWS-LETTER
believe that there has been a long
felt need for a type of news which
would be very difficult for them to
obtain. it is therefore with a
great deal of.pride that they beg
to announce to their readers and
patrons the official appointment
of a new editor to the already
highly capable and efficient staff.
This latest addition is already very
well known and greatly liked by
all, in fact it is not saying too
much to state that he is the best
known man in the University. His
name is George, and he is the
Knight of the Broom, the commander-in-chief of all the janitors,
and it will be in the future his
duty and cherished task to recount
to an expectant public the little
incidents keen during the daily
grind, which he considers worthy
of publication. The editors feel
that George is admirably suited
to hold down this important job,
and as he has a few happenings
that he is just itching to make
public, no more of this valuable
space will be taken up with introductions. Ladies and gentlemen, George for your approval:
The first announcement that I
want to make, fellow students, is
that the next freshman who thinks
my broom closet a good place in
which to consume a lung-duster
had better first get permission
from the Student Council, or I
won't be held responsible for what
happens.
There's been an ungodly lot of
unrekt floating around the premises, so much indeed that it makes
a body think he is a coal miner or
something. Just the other day I
heard Jake Miller criticizing our
brothers down at the Y. M. C. A.
office. Jake claims, and rightly
too, says I, that this year's handbook has proved itself a complete
and utter failure due to the fact
that African golf was omitted
from the list of major sports.
You're entirely correct, Jake, I
second the motion.
And speaking of unrest and
such, unless my old eyes deceive
me, I spied two bold freshmen,
braving the wintry gales and high
seas, fishing from a raft in the
fountain. I surmise that this incident was indirectly connected
with the work or fight law, but I
doubt if the noble fishermen
caught anything, unless it was influenza.
Well, I've got to sweep out the
postoffice now, gents, but I have
a good one up my sleeve about
Dr. Hulburt for next week.

BABES BIOLOGY
PART I—The Fruit Fly.
Why the fruit fly behaves (when
it does behave), that is what we
are to find out. Put into a test
tube, it may go up. Some of us
think it is filled with helium gas;
others argue that it must have
toes So constructed that it is painful to walk downstairs; but my
contention is that, being a fruit
fly, it just naturally goes up, since
fruit grows on branches and not
underground.

In order to get -Hopkins more
before the sporting world, the Athletic Board has authorized the formation of a press bureau at Homewood. The purpose of the agency,
which is headed by Norman Keyes,
is to supply the leading papers in
the East with information upon
the different athletic teams at
Hopkins.
This plan has already been
adopted by many of the leading
colleges, both for the purpose of
advertising their activities to the
general public, especially the
"prep" schools, and to keep the
interest in the Alma Mater going
in the alumni.
The idea of a press agency is
approved by all of the men interested in activities at Hopkins for
it is felt that if the playing schedules of the local teams are to be
extended, interest must be aroused
among the teams of the prospective colleges.
At present, it seems as though
the organization will consist of
the managing editor and one assistant for each sport. It will be
the purpose of Mr. Keyes to select
the candidate if possible from the
teams themselves, so that a personal viewpoint may be had for
the articles. The positions on the
staff will be classed among the,
leading activities at Hopkins.

By B. T. U.
We are now getting our sealegs, as we used to say on the
U. S. S. Algonia. We have time
to pause for reflection now and
then;.and wonder if some of our
campus mysteries will ever be
solved.
•
In the first place where does
all the ice go that they leave at
Gilman Hall every day?
Do the bums that hang around
the flont door of the Barn all day
ever expect to amount to much?
What classes are studying the
unabridged Arabian Nights this
year?
Is Professor Gregory giving the
C. E. seniors a special course in
lacrosse this term.
Where does the Mexican mosquito-eating fish go in the winter
time?
Who invented the new boardwalk on the lower quadrangle?
How much does George charge
to show visitors "The Mummies?"
When is Professor Christie going to take the M. E. seniors on
an inspection trip?
Why do the same fellows get
postoffice boxes year after year
down in the corner by the R. 0.
T. C. bulletin board?
Why does Dr. Latane always
let out his afternoon classes in
history earlier than Dr. French
dismisses his in English composition?
What salaries do our men draw
for giving instruction in electrical
engineering down at Goucher?
Who will be charged up when
the glass trophy case in the Barn
gets smashed?
Why do the track team men
take so long to run up that part
of the cross country course that
borders along Charles street?
Why did the seniors wear clean
collars, clean shaves, and _best
suits last week?

Chess Club Tournament.

As decided at the last meeting
of the Chess Club, the tournament
started at the bekinning of this
week. Several interesting matches
have already been played, and it
appears that it is going to be hard
to select the team. It is thought
that the tournament will be completed by the close of the coming week.
The enrollment of the club has
been slightly increased in the past
week; however, there is plenty of
room for more members, and J.
Zubin, who has been largely instrumental in organizing the club,
wishes to urge every student who
has any knowledge of the game
at all to get into communication
with him.
As is probably known, the club
wishes to make chess a regular
sport at Hopkins. When a team
has been made up, the club intends to arrange several matches
with other universities.

TO AWARD "H"

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club has decided to award an "H"
to those-students who distinguish
themselves in the club's presentations, accordance to certain requirements. The "H" will be in
the form of a 0-old charm of about
one-half inch in length, and is to
be worn on the watch chain. Before taking any definite action on
this matter, the club secured the
sanction a the University authorities. C. T. Leber, president of
the Dramatic Club, received the
following letter of ratification
from Dr. J. C. French, chairman
of the Student Affairs Committee:
"The Faculty Committee on
Student Affairs approves the proposal of the Dramatic Club to
to its members, with
award an
the following stipulations which
have in
I understand you already'
view:
"1. They feel that the'H'should
be granted only to men who have
represented the University by
creditable performances of a part
in one or more plays given for the
general public.
"2. The assignment of a student
to a, place in the cast,is to be the
act of an impartial coach, and
not, in any event, the result of a
vote by members of the club.
"The committee feels that the
athletic 'H' and the debating 'H'
are thus given only for public performances, and are awarded to
men who win their places as the
result of the decision of coaches
who are really college officers. I
have explained to the other members of the committee that it is
'the practice of the club to follow
implicitly the judgment of the
coach in making up the cast, and
that, although this coach has no
standing as a member of the faculty, as has Mr. Murphy, for exmple, the cases are in effect parshould
allel. We feel that an
lie granted only when the right to
award it seems clearly won, and
that the privilege of awarding it
should be extended to college activities very conservatively. Personally, I feel sure that its use by
the Dramatic Club is altogether
desirable."

the following section comprises a
part of the constitution of the
club:

Frank Vigor Morley, '19, son of
Dr. Frank Morley, professor of
mathematics at Johns Hopkins
University, has been selected for
the Rhodes scholarship at Oxford
University, England. It is an
astonishing fact that he is the
third member of his family to receive- this honor. His brother,
Christopher Morley, the widely
known writer, was at New College, Oxford, from 1910 to 1913.
Among the books written by
Christopher Morley are: "The
Eighth Sin," "Parnassus on
Wheels," "Sandy Shandygaff" and
"The
aunted Bookshop." Another brother, Felix M. Morley, is
just beginning his term at Oxford.
He is a, deferred Rhodes scholar
of 1917.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 11, '1919.

10

STRIKERS' CASE HEARD
Miss Matyas, Unionized Worker, Tells
Class in Labor Problems of the Steel
Strike —"History Soaked in
Blood," She Says.

Last week, Dr. Broadus Mitchell introduced an innovation at
Hopkins by inviting Miss Matyas,
a representative of the shirtmakers' union, to speak to the
class in labor problems. The union
with which Miss Matyas is connected is, of course, entirely in
sympathy with the steel strike and
has pledged a considerable sum of
money to help the strikers. In
addition, some of its members are
conducting a publicity campaign
to bring the facts of the steel
strike before the public.
The speaker was in all probability biased in her views, she was
very radical and her manner was
excited enough to bespeak some
fanaticism.
Her statements, which she supported with affidavits, were certainly startling. She began by
saying that contrary to the general belief, the steel employees
worked seven days a week, each
man worked for two weeks 10
hours a day, then shifted to work
14 hours a night. Not infrequently, she claimed, during the shift
period they worked 24 or even 36
hours continuously. Although the
artists of the trade, the rollers
(one man in ten thousand), got
as high as $20 per day, the average
pay of the steel workers is only
40 cents an hour.
Miss Matyas then left the argument in justification of the steel
strike and proceeded to recount
the miseries that have been endured in the towns of Pennsylvania since the walkout. She
claims that the history of the
strike is "soaked in blood." Instead of preserving law and order, the •state constabulary are
committing murders of the most
gruesome kind. Three men talking in the streets constitute a riot,
and the police are active in beating and shooting the strikers without justification. In some instances they have tortured the
men, their wives and children,
without bringing them to justice.
Fi•om midnight to 4 o'clock A. M.
terror reigns. Lawless urchins
are deputized by the police, armed,
and sent out to preserve order.

LIFE-WORK TALKS
BY PROMINENT MEN.

Dr. French imparts the follow:.
ing news concerning an innoVation which will be established at
the Johns Hopkins University
within the next few weeks: The
Y. M. C. A. and the English Department will co-operate in arranging a series of life-work talks
by prominent men, which will be
given primarily to the freshman
English composition class, although all other 'undergraduates
will be urged to attend. The presence of students taking English I
will be obligatory. The plan is to
have these talks on probably the
second Friday of each month
throughout the year, from 12 to
12.30 o'clock. Instructors of 11.30to-12.20 classes will be asked to
dismiss them at five minutes to
12. It is hoped to secure as the
first speaker, Dr. William Welch,
head of the new School of Hygiene
and Public Health and one of the
leading pathologists in the world.
The Hon. Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War, as well as other
well-known men, will also be asked
to address these assemblies. Very
likely the lecturer will be limited
to twenty or twenty-five minutes,
so that the rest of the period may
be :utilized for Student Council
speeches, yells and songs, and announcements. The affair . will be
virtually a college mass-meeting,
an institution which, is a feature
of most American universities.

STUDIES HARASS SWIMMERS;
TRAINING TO BE AT B. A. C.

The swimming team seems to be
making fairly good progress in its
training work. About a third of
the best swimmers, however, are
on the blacklist, which is discouraging. It is hoped, however,
they will have passed off • their
conditions sometime before the
first meet. The team is negotiating at present for the use of the
Baltimore Athletic Club pool, one
of the finest in the city.

The "23d" Psalm.

1. The sophs are my guardians,
I wish they were not.
2. They maketh me to march
around on the green campus: they
leadeth me beside deep waters.
3. They torture my soul: they
forbid me walk the stairs of my
chosing, for their amusement's
sake.
4. Yea, though I walk with a
soft tread, they are sure to hear
me:for they are not lenient; their
rods and their staves they comfort me not.
' 5. They prepareth for me, for
they are mine enemies: they covereth my head with ridicule; my
patience runneth over.
6. Surely trouble and humiliation shall follow me all of my
plebe days: and I will dwell in
peace and security forever after.
—TM Tartan.

The Williams Memorial Expedition to South America consisted
of Prof. Edward W. Berry, professor of paleontology; Prof. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., associate
professor of economic geology,
and Mr. Luis Sbanez Velasco, a
graduate student in the Department of Geology and a native of

PROF. JOSEPH T. SINGEWALD. JR.

Bolivia. The party sailed from
New York on April 17 and reached
Callao, Peru, on May 9. Stops
were made at Port au Prince,
Haiti, in the Canal Zone and at
the Peruvian ports of Eku, Paeas,
mayo and Salaverry en route to
Callao, which afforded brief opportunities for the members of
the expedition to go ashore and
make hasty observations on the
local geology. A week was spent
at Lima, the capital of Peru, in
getting acquainted with the Peruvian geologists and mining engineers, studying the collections of
the Peruvian Bureau of Mines and
Mining School, and making short
excursions to nearby points of geologic interest.
On May 16 the main range of
the Andes was crossed by rail
and the end of the line reached
at Huancayo. The following day
a trip on mule-back over the
range again and back to the sea
at Pisco was commenced, which
lasted until June 2 and which required traveling 250 miles on
mules. En route stops were made
at the mining districts of Huancavelica and Santa Ines. The

The intelligence tests on students entering the Department of
Engineering are intended as an
experiment to determine whether
it is possible to substitute for the
present method of entrance examinations some other form of
test which would determine the
fitness of the student to follow
courses in the University and
also his fitness for entering the
profession of engineering.
Present methods of examination are believed to work hardships in a number of cases and
to keep out a number of students
who would undoubtedly make successful engineers. On the other
hand, the present method does admit students who have acquired
a certain facility in preparing particular subjects and passing written examinations on them. These
students in some cases fail to
show special aptitude for the profession of engineering. The tests
give the student an opportunity
to demonstrate how well he can
use whatever information he has
on relatively simple but normal
problems and to bring out such
special talents as he may have,
leading to particular vocational
service.
The tests will be held on two
days and are six in number, three
on each day. The tests of the
first day are in simple mathematical or common sense problems.
Those on the second day are intended to test the special fitness
of the student for the profession
of engineering. These embrace
certain psychological tests and
simple questions in physics and
everyday technical information.
The tests are in no wise intended
to investigate the knowledge of
the student in the particular subject, but rather the facility with
which he can apply such common
knowledge as he should certainly
already possess.
When these several tests have
been checked up against subsequent scholastic performance and
possibly with some criteria of professional success, it should be possible to ascertain whether and in
what direction we should make
changes in our present methods
of examination:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 11, 1919.

3

NEWSHOLME TO GIVE LECTURES J. H. U. SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION

Debating Council Considers Rules to
Govern Annual Triangle Debate—
Southern Oratorical Contest
March the Fifth.

Elaborate Plan of Lectures Formed in
School of Hygiene. and Public
Health—Attendance Open
to All Students.

Scientific Association Reorganized—illustrated Lecture Given by Mr.
Cockayne of New Zealand-Prof.
Ames is the Chairman.

At the last meeting of the Debating Council the chief topics of
dirassion were the method of
Judging the, triangle debate for
1920 and what the subject should
be. The problem that presented
the most difficulty was how to
have the teams debate on homeground and at the same time obtain impartial judges. North Carolina and Virginia, both situated in
small towns, experience more
difficulty in obtaining these results than does Johns Hopkins,
who can select its judges from all
Baltimore. It was finally decided,
liowever to indorse a new plan instigated by Virginia, namely, to
call in an outside professional
judge and pay him to render his
decision with the reasons for his
conclusions.
Several possible subjects were
discussed and were finally mailed
to North Carolina and Virginia,
for their approval, in the following order:
1. That all labor disputes on
railroads and in coal mines should
be settled by compulsory arbitration if agreement cannot otherwise be reached.
2. That the city manager plan
Should be adopted in Americium
municipalities.
3. That the railroads of the
United States should be nationalized under a plan whereby'control
would be equally divided among
representatives of management, Of
labor and of the public.
The Council is especially anxious to get the topic selected, so
that the junior-senior debate can
be held before Christmas and
thereby spread the literary contests more evenly over the entire
year.

Lectures on "Public Health Administration" and on "Epidemiology" in relation thereto, by Sir
Arthur Newsholme, K. C. B., M.
D., will be given at 5 o'clock P.
M. on Tuesdays and Thursdays,
beginning Tuesday, October 7, at
the School of Hygiene and Public
Health, 312 West Monument
street. While intended primarily
for students in the School of Hygiene and Public Health, the lectures are open to students in
other departments of the University, and especially to those interested in public health work.
The following topics will be
discussed:
PART I.
1. History of public health administration, central and local.
2. Relation of health officers to
local and central authorities.
3. Qualifications and terms of
appointment of health officers.
4. Interrelations of public
health administration.
5. Public health administration in relation to medical and
nursing practitioners.
6. Registration and notification of births, deaths and sickness.

The plans of the association for
this year is to arrange for four
lectures, the last of which will be
followed by a dinner. These lectures will be _delivered by prominent speakers fro-m various fields
of science and who are not connected with the University.
The first of the series of four
regular meetings was held in the
geology laboratory, Civil Engineering Hall, on Wednesday,. November 5 at 5 o'clock P. M. Mr.
Alfred fl. Cockayne, government
biologist of the Dominion of New
Zealand, gave a long, illustrated
lecture on "The Vegetation of New
Zealand and Its Relation to Agriculture." Mr. Cockayne's lecture
was primarily of interest to biologists, but the statements he made
were of equal interest to the eco-.
mimic geologist and to the student
of nature. There were excellent
illustrations of diverse tropical
trees and shrubs, especially of the
perching variety and of the vegethtion in very damp climates,
where plants develop breathing
roots. Over one-fourth of the four
thousand miles of seacoast of the
New Zealand Islands is covered by
sand dunes. Attempts have been
made to harness these migrating
dunes, and several illustrations
were shown to demonstrate how
acres and acres of sandy land
have been fixed by sedges and
other vegetation.
The lectures are open to any interested persons, and will be duly
announced.

BALTIMORE, MD:,

NOV. 11, 1919

Spirit and Cash Wanted.

Let us catch the spirit at the
- mass-meeting next Wednesday. It
is for the purpose of rousing enthusiasm for the new dormitory.
We don't think it needs much
rousing. It is what Hopkins men
have been dreaming of for generations, and none will be so affected
as the present undergraduates.
But enthusiasm backed with
practical means will count more
than enthusiasm alone. Ten dollars from every undergraduate is
not much, viewed singly, but collectively it will help a lot.
A Challenge.

Two little freshmen sat in the
middle of the fountain, on a rickety crate, fishing, and smiling
naively=as a freshman should
smile, — at the howling sophs
grouped around. They were thus
being ignominiously punished for
some infraction of the freshman
regulations.
It was amusing, of course, but
this incident had a deeper significance. It was one of the many
little signs of an undercurrent of
life and spirit around the University. Hazing has formerly been
considered a part of college life.
Now it is forbidden by the Dean.
But he does sanction harmless
punishment of freshmen who are
not inclined to behave as "freshies" should. And it is gratifying
to see the way the sophomore vigilance committee is taking care of

incorrigibles and those who do
not know any better.
This type of interest is a good
sign of college spirit, and has
been most efficacious in swelling
the attendance of first year men
in the rooting section at football
games, and in constraining them
to a closer observance of the "ten
commandments"; but, college
spirit in general should be more
constructive than primitive. There
should be a still larger participation in activities and in the support of our teams.
The only way to get anything
out of college life is to put something into it. There are some
among us who carry more than
their share of college honors and
unfortunately there are some indifferent ones, who selfishly lead
the life of a studious hermit.
These should observe that they
are robbing themselves of unnumbered delights and benefits
that the others are enjoying. They
too, can feel the spirit of Hopkins, and reap lifelong benefits
from the experience and pleasant
associations obtained while taking part in undergraduate life,
and becoming identified with
some particular activities. There
are honors for all who would
achieve them.
A Relic of Barbarism.

Should one wish to see a
Twentieth Century survival of the
day when decades ago our primeval ancestors found it necessary
to Dght in order to eat, let him
venture—if he dares—into the
'basement of "The Barn," where
at lunch time there is staged
daily a battle royal, all for a
sandwich and a bottle of milk.
In a small room is placed a
still smaller counter, from behind which are dispensed a limited supply of not altogether nutritious sandwiches, pies of the
ultra-indigestible variety, candies
and pint bottles • of milk with
straws thrown in- as a means of
imbibition. Somewhat fagged from
a morning of classes, the student
enters "The Barn," knowing what
is ahead of him, and resigns himself to his fate. He is at once
lost in a milling, moiling mass of
humanity, struggling with belligerent, determined elbows to reach
t' at common goal, the counter.
At last he gets there and grabs;
then comes the fight to get out
through the hungry mob, who
press with unyielding force towards the fodder.
By some miracle he escapes,
and sinks exhausted into an empty seat, if there is yet one of the
few vacant. He devours with
avidity what is left of his purchase, chats with some fellow sufferer, and then returns to classroom or to laboratory more tired
than before—of course sufficiently
nourished to get something out of
an afternoon of hard work.
It would seem that enough has
been said. That a hungry, or improperly nourished man can not

accomplish much in mental endeavors is known to everyone.
Something must be done to give
Hopkins students, who can not
conveniently get a decent lunch
elsewhere, a wholesome lunch here
on the campus.
A Laboratory Expe, iment in Labor
Problems.

The talk of liss Matyas to the
class in Political Economy IV was
very interesting. She presented
the cake, and told the story from
the workers' point of view, and in
that respect her talk might be regarded as a laboratory experiment
in labor problems. We hope that
the University will continue this
broad policy of having people actually engaged in practical affairs
talk to the students on topics of
such vital interest. "Veritas vos
Liberabit" be our motto and let
us not fail to avail ourselves of
every opportunity to learn the
truth of such matters.
In this connection, also, THE
NEWS-LETTER COmmendS the effort
of the Social Science Club in making an effort to study the real
problems of life.
Mass-meeting.

Hoffman opened the mass-meeting of last Friday by lamenting
the poor attendance at the meeting. With 800 students at the
University the hall should have
been packed, but it was not. He
then announced that there would
be a mass-meeting on next Wednesday for the benefit of the
$300,000 meniorial dormitory.
Jones then congratulated the
freshmen on their good showing
at the games.
Leber made the following announcements: Money will be collected next Friday to get bands,
if enough money is raised there
will, be bands at each of the three
games. On the night before the
St. John's game a bonfire will be
lighted where the hangar stood.
Each freshman sometime during
that day must report to a member
of the sophomore "Pep" Committee with some boxes or barrels. After the fire a parade
will proceed throughout the city.
On the day of the Western Maryland game all the freshmen will
carry banners bearing the inscription, "Beat Western Maryland !"
On the (lay of the St. John's
game a column Vill be formed at
1 o'clock at Mt. Royal avenue and
Calvert street extending to Homewood.
After , these announcements,
there was a yell practice.
The University of Wisconsin
has had a record-breaking registration this year. A student body
of 6,800 men and women has entered the school making an attendance of nearly 2,000 more than
at any time in the past.

Quacks From A Quack.

The editors Of THE NEWS-LETTER
believe that there has been a long
felt need for a type of news which
would be very difficult for them to
obtain. it is therefore with a
great deal of.pride that they beg
to announce to their readers and
patrons the official appointment
of a new editor to the already
highly capable and efficient staff.
This latest addition is already very
well known and greatly liked by
all, in fact it is not saying too
much to state that he is the best
known man in the University. His
name is George, and he is the
Knight of the Broom, the commander-in-chief of all the janitors,
and it will be in the future his
duty and cherished task to recount
to an expectant public the little
incidents keen during the daily
grind, which he considers worthy
of publication. The editors feel
that George is admirably suited
to hold down this important job,
and as he has a few happenings
that he is just itching to make
public, no more of this valuable
space will be taken up with introductions. Ladies and gentlemen, George for your approval:
The first announcement that I
want to make, fellow students, is
that the next freshman who thinks
my broom closet a good place in
which to consume a lung-duster
had better first get permission
from the Student Council, or I
won't be held responsible for what
happens.
There's been an ungodly lot of
unrekt floating around the premises, so much indeed that it makes
a body think he is a coal miner or
something. Just the other day I
heard Jake Miller criticizing our
brothers down at the Y. M. C. A.
office. Jake claims, and rightly
too, says I, that this year's handbook has proved itself a complete
and utter failure due to the fact
that African golf was omitted
from the list of major sports.
You're entirely correct, Jake, I
second the motion.
And speaking of unrest and
such, unless my old eyes deceive
me, I spied two bold freshmen,
braving the wintry gales and high
seas, fishing from a raft in the
fountain. I surmise that this incident was indirectly connected
with the work or fight law, but I
doubt if the noble fishermen
caught anything, unless it was influenza.
Well, I've got to sweep out the
postoffice now, gents, but I have
a good one up my sleeve about
Dr. Hulburt for next week.
The library of the School of Hygiene and Public Health now contains} 1,167 books and about 1,754
periodicals, totaling 2,921 volumes, an increase of 1,655 volumes
since November, 1918. A large
number. of foreign books are coining in and another room is needed
to house this new material.

BABES BIOLOGY
PART I—The Fruit Fly.
Why the fruit fly behaves (when
it does behave), that is what we
are to find out. Put into a test
tube, it may go up. Some of us
think it is filled with helium gas;
others argue that it must have
toes So constructed that it is painful to walk downstairs; but my
contention is that, being a fruit
fly, it just naturally goes up, since
fruit grows on branches and not
underground.

Keyes Heads New Agency—Purposed
to Advertise Hopkins Sports.

SH-H-H! — MYSTERY

In order to get -Hopkins more
before the sporting world, the Athletic Board has authorized the formation of a press bureau at Homewood. The purpose of the agency,
which is headed by Norman Keyes,
is to supply the leading papers in
the East with information upon
the different athletic teams at
Hopkins.
This plan has already been
adopted by many of the leading
colleges, both for the purpose of
advertising their activities to the
general public, especially the
"prep" schools, and to keep the
interest in the Alma Mater going
in the alumni.
The idea of a press agency is
approved by all of the men interested in activities at Hopkins for
it is felt that if the playing schedules of the local teams are to be
extended, interest must be aroused
among the teams of the prospective colleges.
At present, it seems as though
the organization will consist of
the managing editor and one assistant for each sport. It will be
the purpose of Mr. Keyes to select
the candidate if possible from the
teams themselves, so that a personal viewpoint may be had for
the articles. The positions on the
staff will be classed among the,
leading activities at Hopkins.

By B. T. U.
We are now getting our sealegs, as we used to say on the
U. S. S. Algonia. We have time
to pause for reflection now and
then;.and wonder if some of our
campus mysteries will ever be
solved.
•
In the first place where does
all the ice go that they leave at
Gilman Hall every day?
Do the bums that hang around
the flont door of the Barn all day
ever expect to amount to much?
What classes are studying the
unabridged Arabian Nights this
year?
Is Professor Gregory giving the
C. E. seniors a special course in
lacrosse this term.
Where does the Mexican mosquito-eating fish go in the winter
time?
Who invented the new boardwalk on the lower quadrangle?
How much does George charge
to show visitors "The Mummies?"
When is Professor Christie going to take the M. E. seniors on
an inspection trip?
Why do the same fellows get
postoffice boxes year after year
down in the corner by the R. 0.
T. C. bulletin board?
Why does Dr. Latane always
let out his afternoon classes in
history earlier than Dr. French
dismisses his in English composition?
What salaries do our men draw
for giving instruction in electrical
engineering down at Goucher?
Who will be charged up when
the glass trophy case in the Barn
gets smashed?
Why do the track team men
take so long to run up that part
of the cross country course that
borders along Charles street?
Why did the seniors wear clean
collars, clean shaves, and _best
suits last week?

Chess Club Tournament.

As decided at the last meeting
of the Chess Club, the tournament
started at the bekinning of this
week. Several interesting matches
have already been played, and it
appears that it is going to be hard
to select the team. It is thought
that the tournament will be completed by the close of the coming week.
The enrollment of the club has
been slightly increased in the past
week; however, there is plenty of
room for more members, and J.
Zubin, who has been largely instrumental in organizing the club,
wishes to urge every student who
has any knowledge of the game
at all to get into communication
with him.
As is probably known, the club
wishes to make chess a regular
sport at Hopkins. When a team
has been made up, the club intends to arrange several matches
with other universities.

TO AWARD "H"

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club has decided to award an "H"
to those-students who distinguish
themselves in the club's presentations, accordance to certain requirements. The "H" will be in
the form of a 0-old charm of about
one-half inch in length, and is to
be worn on the watch chain. Before taking any definite action on
this matter, the club secured the
sanction a the University authorities. C. T. Leber, president of
the Dramatic Club, received the
following letter of ratification
from Dr. J. C. French, chairman
of the Student Affairs Committee:
"The Faculty Committee on
Student Affairs approves the proposal of the Dramatic Club to
to its members, with
award an
the following stipulations which
have in
I understand you already'
view:
"1. They feel that the'H'should
be granted only to men who have
represented the University by
creditable performances of a part
in one or more plays given for the
general public.
"2. The assignment of a student
to a, place in the cast,is to be the
act of an impartial coach, and
not, in any event, the result of a
vote by members of the club.
"The committee feels that the
athletic 'H' and the debating 'H'
are thus given only for public performances, and are awarded to
men who win their places as the
result of the decision of coaches
who are really college officers. I
have explained to the other members of the committee that it is
'the practice of the club to follow
implicitly the judgment of the
coach in making up the cast, and
that, although this coach has no
standing as a member of the faculty, as has Mr. Murphy, for exmple, the cases are in effect parshould
allel. We feel that an
lie granted only when the right to
award it seems clearly won, and
that the privilege of awarding it
should be extended to college activities very conservatively. Personally, I feel sure that its use by
the Dramatic Club is altogether
desirable."
In accordance with this sanction,
the following section comprises a
part of the constitution of the
club:
"Any man is allowed to wear
the
after he has made a speaking part of aVer twenty-five lines
for two years."
:Since the definite cast for the
next produ.ction of the club, Barre's "The Admirable evichton,"
has been. announced, it appears
that five students will be qualified
for the dramatic 'H' following the
presentation at Albaugh's Theatre
on the evening of December 22,

Frank Vigor Morley, '19, son of
Dr. Frank Morley, professor of
mathematics at Johns Hopkins
University, has been selected for
the Rhodes scholarship at Oxford
University, England. It is an
astonishing fact that he is the
third member of his family to receive- this honor. His brother,
Christopher Morley, the widely
known writer, was at New College, Oxford, from 1910 to 1913.
Among the books written by
Christopher Morley are: "The
Eighth Sin," "Parnassus on
Wheels," "Sandy Shandygaff" and
"The
aunted Bookshop." Another brother, Felix M. Morley, is
just beginning his term at Oxford.
He is a, deferred Rhodes scholar
of 1917.
Frank V. Morley was graduated
from Johns Hopkins a few years
ago. Since a little time after the
signing of the armistice, Morley
has been doing graduate work in
mathematics and geology. He intends to begin his studies at Oxford next fall.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 11, '1919.

10

STRIKERS' CASE HEARD
Miss Matyas, Unionized Worker, Tells
Class in Labor Problems of the Steel
Strike —"History Soaked in
Blood," She Says.

Last week, Dr. Broadus Mitchell introduced an innovation at
Hopkins by inviting Miss Matyas,
a representative of the shirtmakers' union, to speak to the
class in labor problems. The union
with which Miss Matyas is connected is, of course, entirely in
sympathy with the steel strike and
has pledged a considerable sum of
money to help the strikers. In
addition, some of its members are
conducting a publicity campaign
to bring the facts of the steel
strike before the public.
The speaker was in all probability biased in her views, she was
very radical and her manner was
excited enough to bespeak some
fanaticism.
Her statements, which she supported with affidavits, were certainly startling. She began by
saying that contrary to the general belief, the steel employees
worked seven days a week, each
man worked for two weeks 10
hours a day, then shifted to work
14 hours a night. Not infrequently, she claimed, during the shift
period they worked 24 or even 36
hours continuously. Although the
artists of the trade, the rollers
(one man in ten thousand), got
as high as $20 per day, the average
pay of the steel workers is only
40 cents an hour.
Miss Matyas then left the argument in justification of the steel
strike and proceeded to recount
the miseries that have been endured in the towns of Pennsylvania since the walkout. She
claims that the history of the
strike is "soaked in blood." Instead of preserving law and order, the •state constabulary are
committing murders of the most
gruesome kind. Three men talking in the streets constitute a riot,
and the police are active in beating and shooting the strikers without justification. In some instances they have tortured the
men, their wives and children,
without bringing them to justice.
Fi•om midnight to 4 o'clock A. M.
terror reigns. Lawless urchins
are deputized by the police, armed,
and sent out to preserve order.

LIFE-WORK TALKS
BY PROMINENT MEN.

Dr. French imparts the follow:.
ing news concerning an innoVation which will be established at
the Johns Hopkins University
within the next few weeks: The
Y. M. C. A. and the English Department will co-operate in arranging a series of life-work talks
by prominent men, which will be
given primarily to the freshman
English composition class, although all other 'undergraduates
will be urged to attend. The presence of students taking English I
will be obligatory. The plan is to
have these talks on probably the
second Friday of each month
throughout the year, from 12 to
12.30 o'clock. Instructors of 11.30to-12.20 classes will be asked to
dismiss them at five minutes to
12. It is hoped to secure as the
first speaker, Dr. William Welch,
head of the new School of Hygiene
and Public Health and one of the
leading pathologists in the world.
The Hon. Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War, as well as other
well-known men, will also be asked
to address these assemblies. Very
likely the lecturer will be limited
to twenty or twenty-five minutes,
so that the rest of the period may
be :utilized for Student Council
speeches, yells and songs, and announcements. The affair . will be
virtually a college mass-meeting,
an institution which, is a feature
of most American universities.

STUDIES HARASS SWIMMERS;
TRAINING TO BE AT B. A. C.

The swimming team seems to be
making fairly good progress in its
training work. About a third of
the best swimmers, however, are
on the blacklist, which is discouraging. It is hoped, however,
they will have passed off • their
conditions sometime before the
first meet. The team is negotiating at present for the use of the
Baltimore Athletic Club pool, one
of the finest in the city.

The "23d" Psalm.

1. The sophs are my guardians,
I wish they were not.
2. They maketh me to march
around on the green campus: they
leadeth me beside deep waters.
3. They torture my soul: they
forbid me walk the stairs of my
chosing, for their amusement's
sake.
4. Yea, though I walk with a
soft tread, they are sure to hear
me:for they are not lenient; their
rods and their staves they comfort me not.
' 5. They prepareth for me, for
they are mine enemies: they covereth my head with ridicule; my
patience runneth over.
6. Surely trouble and humiliation shall follow me all of my
plebe days: and I will dwell in
peace and security forever after.
—TM Tartan.
